alternatives.transcript: Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home. I want to show you a very simple, but very straightforward roasted chicken. Simple. I have a beautiful chicken here, 3 pounds, 3, 3 and a half pounds. The first thing that I do when I roast it, I remove the wishbone, which is that triangle here that you have on each side here, you can feel it. You cut on each side, then after with your hand, your finger, just Push it forward to get to the end of it. Then put your finger on the back of it, your thumb on the back of it, and bring it back down. So this is that wishbone here, which is really here. And it's a pain in the neck texturally when you do the carving in the dining room, it's in the way. So I always remove it. Same thing with turkey, duck for that matter. Make sure that when you bite, you have enough that you have a bit of a skin here. The wing, I can bring in the back like this. And I can cook it this way, although I tend to like to truss it so that it holds a better shape. And what I use here, it's butcher twine. Don't use something in plastic. There is about 5 different ways of trussing, with a trussing needle and so forth. This is without needle. And it's relatively simple. I go underneath like this, and you cross above. Then here you go under the drumstick and close it. Then put it on the side here, turn it around, and bringing behind the wing to anchor it. You do, always do a couple, 2 or 3 turn like this because when you tighten it, it doesn't open, you know. So a second thing and that's it. So my chicken is trust, just like it hold a beautiful shape like this. So I'm going to put a tablespoon of butter there in that. And then the seasoning, just salt and pepper. And I have about, you know, the salt inside. Salt it all around. Likewise with the pepper. I will do some inside. And then a little bit on the other side. And I like to start it on the side. See, this is the leg is always longer to cook than the front. So I like to cook it this way, like 20 minutes on this side. Then 20 minutes on the other side. And finally, 20 minutes turning it. And at that point I can, at that point I can baste it. So here, this should be here. So here I would start it on this side here. Roll it a little bit in butter. Then turn it around, go it this way. And that's going to go 425 degrees, 20 minutes this way to start. So my chicken is 20 minutes now. Never go into the breast or whatever, but at the junction here, I go from this side to this side. And as you can see, this side is now beautifully brown. Yeah, so I'm putting on this side for the next 20 minutes. 20 minutes on the other side. And now again, I go on the side. And now here is my chicken. Now I put it on the back. Remember, all that time it was turned upside down. I didn't really have to baste it because the juice was going down and that's why I put it this way. Now, from the gas, so now we start basting it. So start basting it. So every 3, 4 minutes, every, you know, 5, 6 minutes, so you want to baste it a couple of times. It will go there for another 20 minutes, for a total of 1 hour. Beautiful, right? Okay, now my chicken is cooked. As you see, I glazed it a few times. Glaze it like this. Perfect roast chicken. 1 thing that you don't do now, often people do, they cover it with a piece of aluminum foil or whatever. For me, it tends to put moisture in it and the moisture kind of softens it and it ends up being kind of reheated. So here, do you see where I put my fork here, there, but never mind. And I look at the color of the juice. The color is white. Okay, the chicken is cooked. So I put it there and leave it to rest for a couple of minutes before we carve it. Now we do the juice. And of course I could have done it in a pan which is not non-stick. In a sense it would have been better for the sauce because on a non-stick, the crystallization of the juice, it doesn't stay in the bottom of the pan. It's separate. So here I'm going to remove, well, most of the fat. Maybe I leave a tablespoon, tablespoon or 2 of fat. And I will deglaze that with half a cup of chicken stock. But remember that what you have in the bottom, those things here, that's the glaze. That is the juice of the chicken, which solidified in the bottom of the pan. And the process of deglazing is to add liquid to melt all of that type of thing, to melt it. And now I say here, what I want to do here, again, removing the clear fat. And that clear fat is great to saute potato or anything like that. But the bottom, if there is any juice, I add it to this. That's good. Let's see. I could have a dash of salt. I've got a salt here. Maybe I will have a dash of soy just to give me a little bit of color. Okay. So here I have about a good half a cup of natural juice, and I'm going to thicken it with a bit of potato starch. I probably won't use all of that. A little bit of cold liquid you have to do. I have stock here. You always dilute it As soon as that mixture touch the liquid, it thicken on contact. That's why you don't really have to worry that much about how much you put. I put some in it, stir it, and I look at it. Maybe a little more. Until I like the texture that it has. A dash more. Okay. And now I want to show you how to properly carve the chicken. So, First thing, of course, don't forget to remove the twine. This used to be done in the dining room, with a fork and a spoon at that point, you would go on the side, cut the bone here, the skin rather, break it at the bone, it come and it comes out. As you can see, a chicken is perfectly cooked. The other leg in the same way. You cut there and you pull out this. Now here you have the joint of the shoulder. So I look for that joint here, which I have right there, and I cut a piece of the breast. And again, you pull out this. Same thing on the other side. Again, the joint. I go down. You do the same thing with a uncooked chicken, you know? Be exactly the same thing, the same process. And then pull out. Yes. So the 2 legs, the 2 breasts. Now we have what we call le brachet, that is the white meat here. You cut on this and you pull it out. You know, it should come out of the bone pretty easily because it's cooked. Yeah. As you can see, it will come out and you're back, you're left with the whole Carcass like this. And the presentation used to be this. It would be presented this way. The carcass back in. The bone back on top. The wing. The other wing, 1 leg, the other leg. That was a nice presentation. Usually, all right, so with a bunch of watercress, I have a beautiful bunch of watercress here. I will only use the top leaves and of course, this will make a great watercress soup. So, presentation of watercress this way. And of course, we have the juice that we have here, the classic. And this is it. Perfectly raw chicken with natural juice. Happy cooking. ♪♪♪ you

sentences.text: Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home.
I want to show you a very simple, but very straightforward roasted chicken.
Simple.
I have a beautiful chicken here, 3 pounds, 3, 3 and a half pounds.
The first thing that I do when I roast it, I remove the wishbone, which is that triangle here that you have on each side here, you can feel it.
You cut on each side, then after with your hand, your finger, just Push it forward to get to the end of it.
Then put your finger on the back of it, your thumb on the back of it, and bring it back down.
So this is that wishbone here, which is really here.
And it's a pain in the neck texturally when you do the carving in the dining room, it's in the way.
So I always remove it.
Same thing with turkey, duck for that matter.
Make sure that when you bite, you have enough that you have a bit of a skin here.
The wing, I can bring in the back like this.
And I can cook it this way, although I tend to like to truss it so that it holds a better shape.
And what I use here, it's butcher twine.
Don't use something in plastic.
There is about 5 different ways of trussing, with a trussing needle and so forth.
This is without needle.
And it's relatively simple.
I go underneath like this, and you cross above.
Then here you go under the drumstick and close it.
Then put it on the side here, turn it around, and bringing behind the wing to anchor it.
You do, always do a couple, 2 or 3 turn like this because when you tighten it, it doesn't open, you know.
So a second thing and that's it.
So my chicken is trust, just like it hold a beautiful shape like this.
So I'm going to put a tablespoon of butter there in that.
And then the seasoning, just salt and pepper.
And I have about, you know, the salt inside.
Salt it all around.
Likewise with the pepper.
I will do some inside.
And then a little bit on the other side.
And I like to start it on the side.
See, this is the leg is always longer to cook than the front.
So I like to cook it this way, like 20 minutes on this side.
Then 20 minutes on the other side.
And finally, 20 minutes turning it.
And at that point I can, at that point I can baste it.
So here, this should be here.
So here I would start it on this side here.
Roll it a little bit in butter.
Then turn it around, go it this way.
And that's going to go 425 degrees, 20 minutes this way to start.
So my chicken is 20 minutes now.
Never go into the breast or whatever, but at the junction here, I go from this side to this side.
And as you can see, this side is now beautifully brown.
Yeah, so I'm putting on this side for the next 20 minutes.
20 minutes on the other side.
And now again, I go on the side.
And now here is my chicken.

Remember, all that time it was turned upside down.
I didn't really have to baste it because the juice was going down and that's why I put it this way.
Now, from the gas, so now we start basting it.
So start basting it.
So every 3, 4 minutes, every, you know, 5, 6 minutes, so you want to baste it a couple of times.
It will go there for another 20 minutes, for a total of 1 hour.
Beautiful, right?
Okay, now my chicken is cooked.
As you see, I glazed it a few times.
Glaze it like this.
Perfect roast chicken.
1 thing that you don't do now, often people do, they cover it with a piece of aluminum foil or whatever.
For me, it tends to put moisture in it and the moisture kind of softens it and it ends up being kind of reheated.

The color is white.

In a sense it would have been better for the sauce because on a non-stick, the crystallization of the juice, it doesn't stay in the bottom of the pan.

So here I'm going to remove, well, most of the fat.
